td.para: MechDesigner is principally a tool to model, or represent, machines. Particularly machines with many mechanisms and complex tool motions.
We technically know 'Mechanisms' as kinematic-chains.
kinematic-chains represent connected parts in machines. In general, there can be a number of Parts and Joints in a kinematic-chain.
You will know that a car engine is made up of the Piston, Connecting, Rod, Crank, and Cylinder Liner. This is a kinematic-chain. It is a series of connected Parts that has 4 parts and 4 Joints.

list.li: Parts are the physical elements in machines.

td.para: Parts: levers, beams, rams, pistons, Cam-Follower arms, shafts...

list.li: Joints are the connections between the physical elements.

td.para: Joints: rotary bearings, slide-rails and blocks, rod-end bearings.
Parts and Joints are easy to identify, but sometimes less so.
In the image above, the kinematic-chain has:

list.li: Six Parts (the frame is counted as a Part - we call it the Base-Part) and
Seven Joints (six Pin-Joints and one Slide-Joint)

td.para: As of yet, we don't actually know the position of the Parts. You can still move, or drag, the kinematic-chain.
Analysis of the kinematic-chain reveals it has one degree-of-freedom.
However, if you add a dimension to define the position of one Part relative to , then you know the position of all the other Parts.
One dimension will exactly position all of the Parts in the kinematic-chain!
Add a 'Motion-Dimension' to define the position of one Part relative to .
It is exactly like a normal dimension. However, the 'Motion-Dimension' can be continually updated to continually move the kinematic-chain.
In the image above, we have added:

list.li: The Motion-Dimension defines the angle of the Part relative to the Line drawn in the Base-Part.

td.para: We call the Part with a Motion-Dimension a 'Motion-Part' - it is a Part that is driven by a Motion!
The other Parts Dyads - more on Dyads later.
If you change the angle of the 'Motion-Part', all the other Parts that Dyads move to a new position.
The kinematic-chain is a 'kinematically-defined Chain'. An very important concept in MechDesigner.

td.para: The 'kinematically-defined chain' is a kinematic-chain where all the parts are explicitly and exactly positioned by virtue of adding the correct number of Parts, Joints and Motion-Dimensions.
